Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an Inadmissible Class under Immigration Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was it reasonable for the Minister and Solicitor General to issue a certificate identifying Mahdavieh as a member of an inadmissible class under s. 19(1)(g) of the Immigration Act?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mahdavieh admitted to being a MEK member and engaging in fundraising and recruitment; evidence suggested involvement in planning attacks on Iranian embassies; her testimony lacked credibility
Crimes.Court_Ruling: The certificate was upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Membership in MEK, fundraising, recruitment, alleged planning of violent attacks
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Membership in an organization likely to engage in violent acts
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe inadmissibility due to potential violence or organizational membership
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Credibility of testimony, intelligence reports, nature of MEK activities
Crimes.Application_Basis: Belief that individual is inadmissible due to association with violent organization
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Release from detention, cancellation of certificate
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister and Solicitor General may issue certificate if belief exists regarding inadmissibility under s. 40.1
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible denial from Mahdavieh
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential threat to public safety through support of terrorist organization
Crimes.Cause_Description: Illegal entry into Canada and suspected MEK affiliation
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Classified intelligence reviewed by court ex parte
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Reliance on hearsay and classified evidence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Denial of significant involvement despite evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Weight given to intelligence over individual testimony
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Significant involvement with MEK and its violent objectives supported the certificate
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Use of secret evidence without full disclosure to applicant

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on security concerns
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Illegal entry and association with a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of the certificate and release from detention
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Detention and certification by immigration authorities
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Minister of Immigration and Solicitor General
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable grounds for belief in inadmissibility
Crimes.Governing_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in Activities Likely to Endanger Lives or Safety of Persons in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the certificate issued under s. 40.1 reasonable given potential threat to public safety?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Intelligence reports and testimony evaluated for credibility and relevance
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Crown to show reasonable grounds for belief
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Certificate valid if reasonable grounds exist to believe person will engage in violence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of secret evidence in judicial review
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Involvement with MEK and participation in activities supporting violence
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Balancing national security and fairness in use of confidential evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Security intelligence, admissions of MEK membership, recruitment activities
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Argued lack of evidence and unfair process
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Likelihood of engaging in violent acts endangering lives in Canada
Crimes.Pending_Relief_or_Application: Application for habeas corpus or quashing of certificate
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Executive may issue certificate where there are reasonable grounds to believe threat to safety
